benchmark_details.name: Self-Comparison Membership Inference (SMI)
benchmark_details.overview: This paper proposes a novel dataset-level membership inference method based on Self-Comparison, aiming to detect unauthorized usage of copyrighted materials in large language models (LLMs) and vision-language models (VLMs).

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: The primary objective of the benchmark is to provide a method for dataset-level membership inference without requiring access to ground-truth member or non-member data in identical distribution.

data.source: Generated or processed text data derived from various public and proprietary datasets used in LLMs and VLMs.

methodology.calculation: Metrics were calculated based on changes in average negative log-likelihood (A-NLL) before and after paraphrasing, and hypothesis testing was used to infer membership.
methodology.interpretation: An increase in A-NLL indicates that the data is more likely to be part of the training set.
methodology.baseline_results: SMI outperformed traditional membership inference methods on various models and datasets, achieving an average F1 score of 0.984 across assessed scenarios.
methodology.validation: The benchmark was validated through extensive experiments across various datasets and models.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: The benchmark does not require access to ground-truth data, thereby improving privacy by avoiding the need to handle sensitive training material directly.
